title: Evaluating the role of large language models in traditional Chinese medicine diagnosis and treatment recommendations
full_text:
npj |digital medicine Article
Published in partnership with Seoul National University Bundang Hospital
https://doi.org/10.1038/s41746-025-01845-2
Evaluating the role of large language
models in traditional Chinese medicine
diagnosis and treatment
recommendations
Check for updates
Yu Liu1, Yishan Yuan2,K e m i n gY a n1, Yuanyuan Li1, Valeria Sacca1, Sierra Hodges1,M a t t i aC a n n i s t r a1,
Pauline Jeong1,J i a n iW u1 &J i a nK o n g1
Digital health technologies hold signiﬁcant potential for reducing global healthcare disparities. Large
language models (LLMs) offer new opportunities to enhance access to culturally speciﬁc healthcare,
including traditional Chinese medicine (TCM). This study evaluated the diagnostic and treatment
performance of seven publicly available LLMs using a real-world acupuncture case, comparing their
outputs with three professional acupuncturists acrossﬁve domains: Western diagnosis, TCM
diagnosis, acupoint selection, needling technique, and herbal medicine. Twenty-eight expert
evaluators from China, South Korea, and the United States assessed the responses using a
multilingual survey. LLMs performed comparably to acupuncturists in Western diagnosis and showed
variable performance in TCM-speciﬁc tasks. GPT-4o, Qwen 2.5 Max, and Doubao 1.5 Pro
demonstrated the highest alignment with expert evaluations, particularly in TCM diagnosis and
acupoint selection. Theseﬁndings highlight the potential of general-purpose LLMs to support
culturally grounded medical decision-making and reduce access barriers in TCM care systems.
Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) offers therapeutic approaches through
herbal medicine, acupuncture, and Qigong to support neurological disorders1
,2, mental health3,4,p a i n r e l i e f5,6,w o m e n’s health and fertility7,8, cancer care9,10,
chronic conditions11,12, disease prevention13,14, and overall wellness15,16.T h e s e
approaches emphasize personalized treatment based on individual patient
assessment, syndrome differentiation
17, and many other disorders/conditions.
However, global adoption of TCM faces signiﬁcant barriers. Its philosophical
foundations, such as Yin-Yang balance18, ﬁve elements, and Qiﬂow19,a r e
deeply rooted in Chinese philosophy, making them difﬁcult to translate into
global and modern scientiﬁcb i o m e d i c a lm o d e l s20. Additionally, the diag-
nostic approach in TCM also differs signiﬁcantly from modern Western
medicine; while Western protocols typically follow standardized pathways,
TCM adopts a more personalized and nonlinear diagnosis approach
21.T h e s e
philosophical and methodological differences create substantial and funda-
mental cultural and systemic barriers to global reach and adoption of TCM,
affecting broader health equity. Populations unfamiliar with the cultural
context of TCM struggle to fully understand and trust its practices, limiting
their access to its potential beneﬁts. Addressing these cultural disparities is
essential for transforming TCM into a globally inclusive healthcare option.
Recent advances in digital health technologies, particularly large lan-
guage models (LLMs), present an innovative opportunity for making TCM
more globally accessible
22– 25.L L M sh a v ep r o v e nv a l u a b l ei nc l i n i c a ld e c i s i o n
support, diagnostics, and medical documentation26– 29, while also playing an
expanding role in medical education30– 32. Furthermore, their multilingual
capabilities and adaptability enable more inclusive digital health solutions,
ensuring accessibility for diverse populations through culturally and lin-
guistically tailored applications33,34. However, the use of LLMs for TCM
presents unique challenges due to its complex philosophical and linguistic
nuances. For example, adapting LLMs to TCM-speciﬁc tasks such as syn-
drome differentiation, acupuncturepoint selection, and herbal medicine
recommendations, require LLMs to bridge signiﬁcant cultural and theore-
tical gaps
35. Thus, successfully integrating LLMs into TCM practice
demands not only technological advancements but also a deeper under-
standing of cross-cultural medical translation capabilities.
This study aims to evaluate the performance of LLMs in diagnosing
and recommending treatments for a complex real-world acupuncture case
study by comparing the performance of seven general-purpose LLMs with
professional acupuncturists. Speciﬁcally, we test three hypotheses: (1) can
1Department of Psychiatry, Massachusetts General Hospital and Harvard Medical School, Charlestown, MA, USA.2Beijing University of Chinese Medicine,
Beijing, China. e-mail: jkong2@mgh.harvard.edu
npj Digital Medicine|           (2025) 8:466 1
1234567890():,;
1234567890():,;
LLMs provide Western and TCM diagnoses consistent with the assessments
from professional acupuncturists, (2) can LLMs recommend appropriate
acupuncture points and techniques, and (3) can LLMs suggest suitable
herbal medicine combinations. As a pilot benchmarking effort, this study
provides foundational insights into the capabilities and limitations of LLMs
within culturally embedded medical systems such as TCM. By exploring
how scalable AI tools can bridge linguistic, cultural, and geographic gaps in
medical knowledge delivery, ourﬁndings underscore the potential of LLMs
to promote digital health equity and expand global access to culturally
rooted care.
Results
Evaluator characteristics
A total of 28 evaluators participated in the study, with the majority being
female (71.43%) and most falling within the 31~40 age group (42.86%). A
signiﬁcant proportion (85.71%) had active clinical practice experience.
Geographically, evaluators were primarily from China (64.29%), followed
by the United States (21.43%) and South Korea (14.29%). In terms of
education, most held a Doctorate Degree (75.00%), while others had post-
doctoral training (10.71%), a master’s degree (7.14%), or a bachelor’sd e g r e e
(7.14%). Academic titles varied, with 25.00% as Full Professors/Chief
Physicians, 25.00% serving as Associate Professors/Associate Chief Physi-
cians, 17.86% as Assistant Professors/Attending Physicians, 10.71% as
Lecturers/Instructors/Residents, and 7.14% as Postdoctoral Fellows. These
characteristics reﬂect a diverse and experienced group of evaluators. These
demographic details are summarized in Table1.
Performance comparison in Western medical diagnosis
accuracy
The ANOVA analysis showed no signiﬁcant differences in Western medical
diagnosis performance across groups (p = 0.953), indicating that all LLMs
demonstrated capabilities comparable to professional acupuncturists. The
mean scores (±standard deviation) for each source were: Gemini
(4.36 ± 0.87), GPT (4.25 ± 0.80), Qwen (4.14 ± 1.30), Acupuncturist 1
(4.14 ± 1.27), Acupuncturist 3 (4.11 ± 1.31), Acupuncturist 2 (4.04 ± 1.45),
LLaMA (4.00 ± 1.28), Claude (4.00± 1.05), Doubao (4.00 ± 1.31), and
ERNIE (3.89 ± 1.26). These results suggest that all evaluated LLMs per-
formed at levels statistically indistinguishable from human acupuncturists
in Western medical diagnostic assessments. All detailed performance results
are summarized in Table2,T a b l e3,F i g .1.
Performance comparison in TCM diagnosis accuracy
The ANOVA analysis showed signiﬁcant differences in TCM diagnosis
performance across groups (p = 0.008). The ranking was as follows: Acu-
puncturist 3 (4.21 ± 0.92) > Acupuncturist 1 = Acupuncturist 2 (4.14 ± 0.89,
4.14 ± 1.15) > Qwen (3.93 ± 1.05) > LLaMA (3.57 ± 1.23) > GPT = ERNIE =
Doubao (3.54 ± 1.17, 3.54 ± 1.29, 3.54 ± 1.10) > Claude (3.46 ± 1.17) >
Gemini (3.21 ± 1.42). Pairwise comparisons revealed that Gemini scored
signiﬁcantly lower than Acupuncturist 3 (p = 0.04). No signiﬁcant differences
were observed between the LLMs and other professional acupuncturists.
Performance comparison in acupoint selection appropriateness
The ANOVA analysis revealed signiﬁcant differences in acupoint selection
performance across groups (p < 0.001). The ranking from highest to lowest
scores was as follows: Acupuncturist 1 (4.25 ± 0.70) > Acupuncturist 2
(4.07 ± 0.90) > Qwen (3.89 ± 0.83) > GPT (3.82 ± 0.72) > Acupuncturist 3
(3.75 ± 0.80) > Doubao (3.50 ± 0.79) > Claude (3.21 ± 1.10) > LLaMA =
ERNIE (3.14 ± 1.08) > Gemini (3.04 ± 1.07). Pairwise comparisons showed
that Qwen and GPT signiﬁcantly outperformed Gemini (p =0 . 0 2a n dp =0 . 0 5 ,
respectively). Qwen, GPT, and Doubao exhibited no statistically signiﬁcant
differences across comparisons with Acupuncturists 1, 2, or 3 (allp > 0.05).
Performance comparison in needling technique practicability
The ANOVA analysis showed signiﬁcant differences in needling technique
performance across groups (p < 0.001). From highest to lowest scores, the
ranking was as follows: Acupuncturist 1 (4.04 ± 0.79) > Acupuncturist 2
(3.86 ± 1.18) > Acupuncturist 3 (3.75 ± 0.70) > GPT (3.71 ± 0.81) > Doubao
(3.68 ± 0.90) > Qwen (3.43 ± 1.14) > ERNIE (3.36 ± 1.06) > Gemini
(3.14 ± 1.01) > LLaMA (3.04 ± 1.20) > Claude (2.93 ± 1.05). Pairwise com-
parisons revealed no statistically signiﬁcant differences among the LLMs
(p > 0.05). Similarly, no signiﬁcant differences were found between GPT,
Doubao, Qwen, ERNIE and any of thethree acupuncturists (p > 0.05).
Performance comparison in herbal prescription suitability
The ANOVA analysis revealed signiﬁcant differences in herbal med-
icine recommendations across groups (p = 0.001). The ranking from
highest to lowest score was as follows: Acupuncturist 2 (4.07 ± 1.02) =
Acupuncturist 3 (4.07 ± 0.77) > Acupuncturist 1 (3.39 ± 0.92) > Qwen
(3.36 ± 1.19) = LLaMA (3.36 ± 0.99) > Doubao (3.32 ± 0.98) > GPT
(3.29 ± 1.15) > ERNIE (3.25 ± 1.08) > Gemini (3.07 ± 1.41) > Claude
(3.04 ± 1.14). Pairwise comparisons revealed no statistically signiﬁcant
differences among the LLMs (p > 0.05). Acupuncturist 2 and Acu-
puncturist 3 demonstrated statist ically comparable performance to
Qwen, LLaMA, Doubao, GPT, and ERNIE (all p > 0.05) but sig-
niﬁcantly outperformed Gemini and Claude (allp < 0.05).
Overall diagnostic and treatment performance evaluation
The ANOVA analysis revealed signiﬁcant differences in overall perfor-
mance across groups (p = 0.002). From highest to lowest total score, the

performance ranking was as follows: Acupuncturist 2 (20.18 ± 4.23) >

2( p = 0.05).
High-scoring ratio across LLMs and acupuncturists
The proportions/ratios of high-scoring recommendations (≥4) across all
evaluators reveal notable performance differences between LLMs and acu-
puncturists across variousevaluation criteria (Table4). In Western medical
diagnosis, acupuncturists achieved high-score ratios ranging from 78.6% to
82.1%, LLMs varied between 67.9% and 82.1%, with Gemini performing best
(82.1%). For TCM diagnosis, acupuncturists demonstrated high-score ratios
from 78.6% to 85.7%, while LLMs exhibited greater variability (42.9% to
7 5 . 0 % ) ,w i t hQ w e nl e a d i n ga m o n gL L M s( 7 5 . 0 % ) .I na c u p o i n ts e l e c t i o n ,t h e
proportions of acupuncturists ranged from 53.6% and 85.7%, LLMs ranged
from 32.1% to 71.4%, with GPT achieving the highest LLM score. Similarly,
for needling techniques, acupuncturists ranged from 60.7% to 78.6% com-
pared to LLMs (25.0% to 67.9%), where GPT ranked highest. In herbal
medicine, acupuncturists scored between 42.9% and 75.0%, exceeding LLMs,
which ranged from 28.6% to 42.9%, with Qwen and Gemini performing best
(42.9%). Chi-square test results indicate signiﬁcant differences in TCM
diagnosis (p < 0.001), acupoint selection (p < 0.001), needling techniques
(p < 0.001), and herbal medicine prescriptions (p = 0.004), whereas no sig-
niﬁcant variation was observed in Western medicald i a g n o s i s(p =0 . 9 3 ) .
Discussion
In this study, we conducted a case-based evaluation of seven publicly
accessible LLMs and compared their diagnostic and treatment recom-
mendations with those of experiencedacupuncturists using a real-world
TCM case. We found that (1) certain LLMs, including GPT-4o, Qwen 2.5
Max, and Doubao 1.5 Pro, demonstrated performance comparable to
licensed acupuncturists in speciﬁc domains such as TCM diagnosis, acu-
point selection, and herbal treatment planning, and (2) performance varied
substantially across models and tasks, indicating inconsistency in current
capabilities. Theseﬁndings suggest that general-purpose LLMs possess
foundational potential to support culturally embedded healthcare systems
like TCM. With targeted reﬁnement, they may serve as scalable and cost-
effective tools to expand access to high-quality, culturally relevant care,
particularly in settings where linguistic, geographic, or infrastructural bar-
riers limit the availability of trained practitioners.
Our ﬁndings demonstrated exceptional performance in the Western
medical diagnostic capabilities of LLMs. In addition, we found that three
models, GPT, Qwen, and Doubao, achieved performance comparable to
human acupuncturists in TCM diagnosis and acupoint selection, while
showing more variability in needling techniques and herbal formulation. This
ﬁnding is consistent with broader evaluations where LLMs have shown high
accuracy in structured and rule-based assessments, such as medical board
examinations
36– 38. These models exhibit a robust understanding of standar-
dized protocols and diagnostic criteria, enabling them to deliver promising
results that match or even surpass human expertise in some scenarios.
Additionally, the multilingual processing capabilities of LLMs also present
another signiﬁcant advantage in global healthcare applications. LLMs
demonstrated proﬁciency in aligning with clinicalguidelines across linguistic
barriers, making accurate recommendations in various languages39– 41.T h i s
capacity for multilingual processingpromotes equitable access to medical
knowledge and improves global healthcare accessibility.
While LLMs like GPT, Qwen, and Doubao are comparable to profes-
sional acupuncturists in multiple tasks in several key domains, their perfor-
mance was not uniform across all assessment criteria. Although GPT, a
Western-developed model, demonstrated strong performance, Chinese-
developed LLMs, like Qwen and Doubao, outperformed many other models
in handling culturally sensitive TCMtasks. This suggests that both model
architecture and culturally tailored training datasets can enhance perfor-
mance in areas requiring deep cultural adaptability. Our results have
important implications for addressinglongstanding barriers in globalization
of TCM. TCM has historically faced challenges in globalization due to its
complex theoretical foundations, cultural nuances, and differences in edu-
cational systems worldwide
42,43. These barriers make it difﬁcult for interna-
tional practitioners and students to access and integrate TCM knowledge into
their practices. LLMs provide innovative potential to address these challenges
and foster health equity through several processes. First, the ability of LLMs to
process TCM concepts and provide recommendations across multiple lan-
guages addresses linguistic barriers and enables broader engagement with
TCM practices
33,35,44. The strong performance of culturally adapted models
like GPT, Qwen, and Doubao demonstrates the potential for maintaining
Asian cultural authenticity while increasing accessibility of TCM. Further-
more, LLMs’scalability and cost-effectiveness, and digital nature make them
powerful tools for democratizing TCM education and distribution, particu-
larly in regions where access to trained acupuncturists is limited
42,45,46.
Nevertheless, LLMs still face signiﬁcant challenges in handling culturally
sensitive and complex tasks within TCM. Our analysis revealed signiﬁcant
performance disparities among LLMs in TCM-speciﬁct a s k s .N o t a b l y ,
Gemini, LLaMA, Claude, and ERNIE were associated with lower perfor-
mance compared to human acupuncturists in specialized areas such as

acupoint selection and needling techniques. Additionally, Gemini and Claude
underperformed relative to professional acupuncturists in herbal formulation
tasks. In contrast, Qwen and Doubao, along with GPT, consistently achieved
performance levels comparable to acupuncturists in culturally nuanced tasks,
particularly in TCM diagnosis and acupoint selection, while still showing
variability in other domains such as needling techniques and herbal for-
mulation. These models demonstrated better performance than other
models, likely due to their training with more regionally and culturally
relevant data. These performance variations may be primarily inﬂuenced by
model architecture
47,t r a i n i n gd a t a48, ﬁne-tuning49, domain specialization50,
and reasoning ability51. The comparable performance of GPT demonstrates
the impact of its advanced architecture,large-scale parameters, and reasoning
capabilities, allowing it to achieve high diagnostic accuracy even without
explicit cultural optimization52–55. The stronger performance of Chinese-
developed models (Qwen and Doubao) indicates that they might beneﬁtf r o m
targeted optimization for Chinese medical corpora, improving text
comprehension and diagnostic reasoning56. Their integration of Chinese
clinical guidelines and traditional decoction provides a distinct advantage in
culturally sensitive tasks57, with reasoning patterns that more closely align
with those of Chinese physicians. Ourﬁndings highlight fundamental chal-
lenges in applying LLMs to TCM practices, as the diagnostic framework relies
heavily on complex subjective and culturally embedded methods such as
pulse analysis, tongue observation, and syndrome differentiation17,56,58.T h e s e
holistic and dynamic approaches and elements pose additional challenges for
LLMs that are primarily trained on Western medical datasets
57,59.F u r t h e r -
more, the lack of large, standardized datasets speciﬁct oT C Me x a c e r b a t e s
t h e s ei s s u e s ,l e a v i n gm a n yL L M su n a b l et of u l l yr e p l i c a t et h ee x p e r t i s e
required for culturally sensitive TCM practices56. Thus, some LLMs failed to
match the performance of human practitioners in tasks that require cultural
and contextual sensitivity, particularly in TCM diagnosis and treatment.
Several limitations of this study must be acknowledged. First, the eva-
luation was based on a single reported clinical case involving amyotrophic

Score
Fig. 1 | Performance distribution of LLMs and acupuncturists acrossﬁve eva-
luation domains.Violin plots show score distributions for seven LLMs and three
licensed acupuncturists acrossﬁve domains: Western diagnosis, TCM diagnosis,
acupoint selection, needling technique, and herbal medicine. Scores were rated by 28
blinded TCM experts using a 5-point Likert scale. LLM large language model, TCM
Traditional Chinese Medicine.
https://doi.org/10.1038/s41746-025-01845-2 Article
npj Digital Medicine|           (2025) 8:466 6
lateral sclerosis (ALS). While this allowed for a controlled comparison across
multiple domains, it may limit the generalizability of theﬁndings. Broader
validation using diverse case types and disease categories is needed to
determine LLM adaptability in more varied clinical settings. Second, all LLM
responses were generated from structured case texts without real-time
interaction. This non-interactive format does not replicate the real-world
process in which a practitioner interprets a patient’s natural expressions and
then translates them into TCM terms. In clinical settings, TCM diagnosis
often depends on spontaneous patient language, behavioral cues, and subtle
contextual factors that are difﬁcult to capture in standardized written formats.
In addition, while this study evaluated acupoint selection and needling
techniques, it did not assess treatment implementation or patient response,
both of which are critical to therapeutic outcomes in acupuncture. Future
research should incorporate more interactive methodologies, such as clinical
simulations or real patient interviewsusing AI-Agent, to better approximate
real-world diagnostic workﬂows in TCM and evaluate how LLMs perform
under more naturalistic and context-rich conditions. Third, while we used a
ﬁve-domain scoring rubric developed through expert consensus, the fra-
mework has not been externally validated. Although predeﬁned criteria were
applied, some subjectivity in evaluator judgments may remain. Formal
assessment of inter-rater reliability and the development of standardized
evaluation tools tailored to TCM practice are important next steps. Fourth,
the models examined were general-purpose LLMs that had not beenﬁne-
tuned on medical or TCM-speciﬁc corpora. The results should therefore be
interpreted as a baseline assessment of current capabilities. The emergence of
n e w e rm o d e l sa f t e ro u rs t u d y ,s u c ha sD e e p S e e ka n dG o r k ,h i g h l i g h t st h e
n e e df o rc o n t i n u o u se v a l u a t i o na st h eﬁeld rapidly evolves. It is expected that
future domain-specialized models trained on curated TCM datasets will show
improved contextual understanding and clinical accuracy.
To address these limitations and support the responsible integration of
AI into TCM practice, future researchshould prioritize the development of
high-quality, domain-speciﬁc corpora. These should include classical TCM
texts, modern clinical guidelines, trial data, and real-world patient records to
align model outputs with TCM theory, language, and diagnostic reasoning.
Expanding datasets to include diverse cases and longitudinal, multi-case
evaluations will be essential for testing performance across varied clinical
settings.
Furthermore, incorporating AI agents and multimodal diagnostic
inputs, such as tongue images or pulse waveforms, could allow the AI to
communicate with the patient directly to mimic real clinical settings,
enhancing the realism and clinical utility of LLMs. Also, expert-in-the-
loop learning approaches would allow continuous reﬁnement based on
practitioner feedback, while explainable AI tools can support transpar-
ency and clinician trust. From a system-level perspective, cross-cultural
validation and prospective clinical trials will be necessary to determine
whether LLM-informed TCM care improves diagnostic accuracy,
healthcare access, and patient outcomes, particularly in underserved or
resource-constrained environments. These efforts will help deﬁne the role
of LLMs within global digital health ecosystems. Ultimately, advancing the
use of LLMs in TCM requires close collaboration among practitioners, AI
developers, and policy experts. By fostering culturally sensitive, inclusive,
and evidence-based innovation, LLMs can contribute meaningfully to the
mission of digital health equity and support more accessible, high-quality
care for all.
In summary, this study establishes an initial benchmark for evaluating
the diagnostic and treatment capabilities of LLMs in TCM. Using a stan-
dardized clinical case, we found thatwhile general-purpose LLMs demon-
strated performance comparable to licensed acupuncturists in Western
medical diagnosis, their capabilities varied considerably across TCM-
speciﬁc domains. Notably, GPT-4o, Qwen 2.5 Max, and Doubao 1.5 Pro
exhibited the highest alignment with licensed acupuncturists in TCM
diagnosis, acupoint selection,and needling techniques. Theseﬁndings
highlight the potential of LLMs as accessible and scalable tools to support
TCM care, particularly in settings with limited healthcare resources. Future
research should prioritize domain-speciﬁc ﬁne-tuning, AI-agent, multi-
modal input integration, and real-world clinical validation to enhance both
performance and reliability. As LLMs continue to evolve, their thoughtful
integration into TCM practice holds signiﬁcant potential to bridge tradi-
tional medical knowledgewith modern healthcare systems, contributing to
a more equitable and culturally inclusive digital health future.
Methods
Study design
This survey-based study evaluated the diagnostic and treatment recom-
mendations of seven LLMs and three acupuncturists, assessed indepen-
dently by 28 professional acupuncturists. A clinically complex and
educationally representative case of ALS was selected from a peer-
reviewed TCM case report
60. ALS was chosen for its neurological com-
plexity, integration of Western and TCM diagnostic elements, and rele-
vance to acupuncture education and practice in China
61. These
characteristics made it a suitable case example for benchmarking LLM
performance across multiple diagnostic and treatment domains. The case
was reformatted to include detailed patient history, physical examination
ﬁndings, and TCM diagnosis to provide uniform inputs (Supplementary
Table 1). Each LLM and acupuncturist was treated as an independent
“model” and assessed acrossﬁve domains: diagnostic accuracy (Western
and TCM), acupoint selection, needling technique, and herbal prescrip-
tion appropriateness. Blinding and bias mitigation strategies were
implemented to enhance the validity. A detailed overview of the study
design is provided in Fig.2.

Fig. 2 | Study design and evaluation framework of the TCM-LLM
benchmark study.A clinically complex ALS case integrating Western and TCM
diagnostic elements was used. Seven LLMs and three licensed acupuncturists
responded to three standardized prompts. Responses were evaluated acrossﬁve
domains: Western diagnosis, TCM diagnosis, acupoint selection, needling techni-
que, and herbal medicine. Ratings were provided by 28 blinded TCM experts using a
5-point Likert scale. The LLMs included GPT-4o (OpenAI), Gemini 1.5 Flash
(Google), LLaMA 3.2 (Meta), Claude 3.5 Sonnet (Anthropic), ERNIE 3.5 (Baidu),
Qwen 2.5 Max (Alibaba), and Doubao 1.5 Pro (ByteDance). Abbreviations: LLM,
large language model; TCM, Traditional Chinese Medicine; ALS, amyotrophic lat-

https://doi.org/10.1038/s41746-025-01845-2 Article
npj Digital Medicine|           (2025) 8:466 8
Recommendations by LLMs
Given the rapidly expanding landscape of LLMs, selecting models for eva-
luation requires balancing representation across leading international and
domestic developers with the practical need to limit the time and cognitive
demands on expert evaluators. Seven generative LLMs were selected for
evaluation based on the following criteria: (1) representation of leading
international or Chinese developers, including models designed for English
and Chinese language tasks; (2) public availability through free or low-cost
user interfaces to ensure accessibility and reproducibility; and (3) general-
purpose design withoutﬁne-tuning in medicine or TCM, allowing for an
unbiased evaluation of baseline performance in TCM diagnostic and
treatment recommendations.
The models included in this study were GPT-4o (OpenAI), Gemini 1.5
Flash (Google), LLaMA 3.2 (Meta), Claude 3.5 Sonnet (Anthropic), ERNIE
3.5 (Baidu), Qwen 2.5 Max (Alibaba), and Doubao 1.5 Pro (ByteDance).
Detailed speciﬁcations are provided in Supplementary Table 2. All models
were accessed through publicly available user interfaces without any
external plugins or real-time internet access. Therefore, all generated
responses were based solely on the models’pre-trained knowledge available
at the time of data collection. None of the models had been speciﬁcally
trained orﬁne-tuned on medical or TCM data. Each model was tasked with
responding to three prompts designedto assess its ability to translate,
diagnose, and recommend treatments (see Supplementary Table 3):
1. Prompt #1: Please translate the following case report into English. As
the case of a medical questionnaire, the context must be provided
concisely, clearly, coherently, andaccurately. The full case report,
including detailed patient history, physical examination, and TCM
diagnosis, is provided in the supplementary material (Supplementary
Table 1).
2. Prompt #2: Please offer both Western and TCM diagnoses based on
the provided patient information. As the case of a medical ques-
tionnaire, the context must be provided concisely, clearly, coherently,
and accurately (Less than 150 counts).
3. Prompt #3:D e s i g na na c u p u n c t u r et r e a t m e n tp l a nf o rt h i sp a t i e n t ,
including selection of primary and supplementary acupuncture points,
needling techniques, and details on the angle, direction, and depth of
insertion. Additionally, recommend an herbal medicine as adjunct
therapy. As the case of a medical questionnaire, the context must be
provided concisely, clearly, coherently, and accurately (Less than 150
counts).
Recommendations by licensed acupuncturists
To establish a benchmark for evaluating LLMs, experienced TCM acu-
puncturists were recruited based on the following inclusion criteria: (1)
possession of a valid license as a TCM or acupuncture practitioner; (2) a
minimum of eight years of clinical acupuncture experience; (3) active
clinical practice in a hospital or an academic acupuncture department.
Two acupuncturists met these criteria: Acupuncturist 1, MSc, an
attending TCM physician at a hospital in Guangzhou, China, with about ten
years of clinical experience, and Acupuncturist 2, PhD, a full professor in the
Department of Acupuncture, chief physician, and senior clinician at a
hospital in Chengdu, China, with more than ten years of clinical experience.
The third set of clinical responses was extracted from the original peer-
reviewed case report
60, in which the author was identiﬁed as a clinician (with
aM a s t e r’sd e g r e e )a fﬁliated with Tianjin University of Traditional Chinese
Medicine, with about 8 years of clinical experience.
The participating acupuncturists were provided with standardized case
information, identical to what was given to the LLMs through three
prompts, including detailed clinical history, examinationﬁndings, and
preliminary diagnoses. They were not aware of the study’sa i m sb e f o r e
completing their responses to minimize potential bias. Each acupuncturist
was instructed to independently provide a written response, which was
submitted via email. All participants were encouraged to complete their
recommendations independently(see Supplementary Table 3).
Evaluation criteria
The recommendations were evaluated using a 5-point Likert scale across
ﬁve criteria: (1) accuracy of Western medical diagnoses, (2) accuracy of
TCM diagnoses, (3) appropriateness of acupuncture point selection, (4)
practicability of needling techniques, and (5) suitability ofherbal medicine.
Scoring deﬁnitions and thresholds were standardized to ensure consistency
across evaluations (Table5).
Evaluator selection and survey implementation
Professional acupuncturists from China, South Korea, and the United
States participated as independent evaluators to assess the diagnostic and
treatment responses generated by both LLMs and licensed acupuncturists.
Evaluators were selected based on the following criteria: (1) active
involvement in either clinical care or academic activities (e.g., teaching or
research) in acupuncture or TCM; and (2) afﬁliation with a TCM hospital/
clinic or an accredited university/institution. Recruitment was conducted
through email invitations distributed through professional networks,
institutional collaborations of all co-authors, and academic referrals. As a
pilot study designed to provide preliminary insights, a broad pool of
qualiﬁed professionals was invited. Of those invited, 28 evaluators com-
pleted the full assessment within the designated timeframe and were
included in the ﬁnal analysis. To reduce bias, evaluators were not
informed that some responses were generated by LLMs. They were told
that the study aimed to examine variation in diagnostic and treatment
recommendations from different sources. All evaluators were blinded to
the study hypothesis, evaluation criteria, and the identities of the
respondents.
Each evaluator received a standardized survey translated into Chinese,
Korean, or English through a forward-backward translation process to
ensure accuracy and cultural equiv alence. Evaluators independently
reviewed anonymized diagnostic and treatment responses and rated them
using predeﬁned criteria. All responses were submitted anonymously
through the secure online survey platform“Wenjuanxing”
62 (www.wjx.cn)
between November 1 and November 30, 2024.
Bias mitigation
To minimize bias, a standardized evaluation guide with clear scoring deﬁ-
nitions and examples was provided to all evaluators. The order of responses
was randomized, and all identifying labels (e.g.,“AI” or“acupuncturist”)w e r e
removed to ensure impartial assessments. Independent evaluations were
conducted under blinded conditions to prevent inﬂuence by prior responses.
Ethical approval
This study was reviewed and determined to be exempt from full ethical
review by the Mass General Brigham Institutional Review Board (Pro-
tocol #: 2025P001014) under 45 CFR 46.104(d)(2). The research
involved no identiﬁable private information or direct interaction with
human participants, and relied solely on a publicly available, de-
identiﬁed clinical case and anonymous expert survey data. Informed
consent was waived in accordance with relevant policy
63,64. All proce-
dures were conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki
and applicable guidelines
65.
Statistical analysis
Statistical analyses were performed using IBM SPSS Statistics version
29.0.1.0
66. Descriptive statistics were reported as means ± standard devia-
tions for continuous variables and as counts (n) with percentages for cate-
gorical variables. Group differences were assessed using one-way analysis of
variance (ANOVA) for continuous variables, followed by Tukey’sH o n e s t
Signiﬁcant Difference (HSD) test for post-hoc pairwise comparisons when
applicable. Chi-square tests were conducted for categorical variables across
multiple groups. All analyses were two-tailed, with statistical signiﬁcance set
at p < 0.05. Data visualizations weregenerated using GraphPad Prism
version 10.

Data availability
The ﬁnal dataset supporting the conclusions of this study is available from
the corresponding author via email upon reasonable request and pending
institutional approval.
Code availability
No custom algorithms or scripts were developed for this study. Statistical
analyses were conducted using IBM SPSS Statistics (version 29.0.1.0).

Acknowledgements
The authors sincerely thank all participating acupuncturists and expert
evaluators for their valuable time and contributions to the multilingual
assessment process. No external funding was received for this work.
Author contributions
J.K. conceptualized and provided overall supervision. J.K., Y. Liu and Y.Y.
selected the study case, designed the methodology, and constructed the
evaluation framework. Y. Liu and Y. Li performed statistical analysis and data
interpretation. K.Y., Y. Li, P.J. and J.W. coordinated multilingual survey
administration and managed evaluator recruitment, translation, and data
collection via Wenjuanxing. Y. Liu and K.Y. drafted the manuscript and
prepared theﬁgures. J.W., V.S., S.H. and M.C. contributed to manuscript
preparation and revision. Y. Liu and J.W. assembled the submission
package. All authors reviewed and approved theﬁnal manuscript.
